trans-unit.source: <html></html> <html></html>How to log on to the virtual machine after you create it
trans-unit.target: <html></html> <html></html>How to log on to the virtual machine after you create it

trans-unit.source: To manage the settings of the virtual machine and the applications that run on the machine, you can use an SSH client.
trans-unit.target: To manage the settings of the virtual machine and the applications that run on the machine, you can use an SSH client.

trans-unit.source: To do this, you must install an SSH client on your computer that you want to use to access the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: To do this, you must install an SSH client on your computer that you want to use to access the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: There are many SSH client programs that you can choose from.
trans-unit.target: There are many SSH client programs that you can choose from.

trans-unit.source: The following are possible choices:
trans-unit.target: The following are possible choices:

trans-unit.source: If you are using a computer that is running a Windows operating system, you might want to use an SSH client such as PuTTY.
trans-unit.target: If you are using a computer that is running a Windows operating system, you might want to use an SSH client such as PuTTY.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>PuTTY Download</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>PuTTY Download</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If you are using a computer that is running a Linux operating system, you might want to use an SSH client such as OpenSSH.
trans-unit.target: If you are using a computer that is running a Linux operating system, you might want to use an SSH client such as OpenSSH.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>OpenSSH</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>OpenSSH</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to use the PuTTY program to access the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to use the PuTTY program to access the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Find the Host Name and Port information from the Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Find the Host Name and Port information from the Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: You can find the information that you need from the dashboard of the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: You can find the information that you need from the dashboard of the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Click the virtual machine name and look for the SSH Details in the Quick Glance section of the dashboard.
trans-unit.target: Click the virtual machine name and look for the SSH Details in the Quick Glance section of the dashboard.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Find SSH details</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Find SSH details</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Open the PuTTY program.
trans-unit.target: Open the PuTTY program.

trans-unit.source: Enter the Host Name and the Port information that you collected from the dashboard, and then click Open.
trans-unit.target: Enter the Host Name and the Port information that you collected from the dashboard, and then click Open.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Enter the host name and port information</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Enter the host name and port information</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Log on to the virtual machine using the NewUser1 account that you specified when the machine was created.
trans-unit.target: Log on to the virtual machine using the NewUser1 account that you specified when the machine was created.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Log on to the new virtual machine</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Log on to the new virtual machine</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You can now work with the virtual machine just as you would with any other server.
trans-unit.target: You can now work with the virtual machine just as you would with any other server.

trans-unit.source: <html></html> <html></html>How to attach a data disk to the new virtual machine
trans-unit.target: <html></html> <html></html>How to attach a data disk to the new virtual machine

trans-unit.source: Your application may need to store data.
trans-unit.target: Your application may need to store data.

trans-unit.source: To set this up, you attach a data disk to the virtual machine that you previously created.
trans-unit.target: To set this up, you attach a data disk to the virtual machine that you previously created.

trans-unit.source: The easiest way to do this is to attach an empty data disk to the machine.
trans-unit.target: The easiest way to do this is to attach an empty data disk to the machine.

trans-unit.source: Note: Data Disk vs. Resource Disk
trans-unit.target: Note: Data Disk vs. Resource Disk

trans-unit.source: Data Disks reside on Azure Storage and can be used for persistent storage of files and application data.
trans-unit.target: Data Disks reside on Azure Storage and can be used for persistent storage of files and application data.

trans-unit.source: Each virtual machine created also has a temporary local Resource Disk attached.
trans-unit.target: Each virtual machine created also has a temporary local Resource Disk attached.

trans-unit.source: Because data on a resource disk may not be durable across reboots, it is often used by applications and processes running in the virtual machine for transient and temporary storage of data.
trans-unit.target: Because data on a resource disk may not be durable across reboots, it is often used by applications and processes running in the virtual machine for transient and temporary storage of data.

trans-unit.source: It is also used to store page or swap files for the operating system.
trans-unit.target: It is also used to store page or swap files for the operating system.

trans-unit.source: On Linux, the Resource Disk is typically managed by the Azure Linux Agent and automatically mounted to /mnt/resource (or /mnt on Ubuntu images).
trans-unit.target: On Linux, the Resource Disk is typically managed by the Azure Linux Agent and automatically mounted to /mnt/resource (or /mnt on Ubuntu images).

trans-unit.source: Note that the resource disk is a temporary disk, and might be emptied when the VM is deprovisioned.
trans-unit.target: Note that the resource disk is a temporary disk, and might be emptied when the VM is deprovisioned.

trans-unit.source: On the other hand, on Linux the data disk might be named by the kernel as /dev/sdc, and users will need to partition, format and mount that resource.
trans-unit.target: On the other hand, on Linux the data disk might be named by the kernel as /dev/sdc, and users will need to partition, format and mount that resource.

trans-unit.source: Please see the <link><linkText>Azure Linux Agent User Guide</linkText><title></title></link> for more information.
trans-unit.target: Please see the <link><linkText>Azure Linux Agent User Guide</linkText><title></title></link> for more information.

trans-unit.source: If you have not already done so, sign in to the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: If you have not already done so, sign in to the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Click Virtual Machines, and then select the MyTestVM1 virtual machine that you previously created.
trans-unit.target: Click Virtual Machines, and then select the MyTestVM1 virtual machine that you previously created.

trans-unit.source: On the command bar, click Attach, and then click Attach Empty Disk.
trans-unit.target: On the command bar, click Attach, and then click Attach Empty Disk.

trans-unit.source: The Attach Empty Disk dialog box appears.
trans-unit.target: The Attach Empty Disk dialog box appears.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Define disk details</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Define disk details</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The Virtual Machine Name, Storage Location, and File Name are already defined for you.
trans-unit.target: The Virtual Machine Name, Storage Location, and File Name are already defined for you.

trans-unit.source: All you have to do is enter the size that you want for the disk.
trans-unit.target: All you have to do is enter the size that you want for the disk.

trans-unit.source: Type 5 in the Size field.
trans-unit.target: Type 5 in the Size field.

trans-unit.source: Note: All disks are created from a VHD file in Azure storage.
trans-unit.target: Note: All disks are created from a VHD file in Azure storage.

trans-unit.source: You can provide a name for the VHD file that is added to storage, but the name of the disk is automatically generated.
trans-unit.target: You can provide a name for the VHD file that is added to storage, but the name of the disk is automatically generated.

trans-unit.source: Click the check mark to attach the data disk to the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Click the check mark to attach the data disk to the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: You can verify that the data disk is successfully attached to the virtual machine by looking at the dashboard.
trans-unit.target: You can verify that the data disk is successfully attached to the virtual machine by looking at the dashboard.

trans-unit.source: Click the name of the virtual machine to display the dashboard.
trans-unit.target: Click the name of the virtual machine to display the dashboard.

trans-unit.source: The number of disks is now 2 for the virtual machine and the disk that you attached is listed in the Disks table.
trans-unit.target: The number of disks is now 2 for the virtual machine and the disk that you attached is listed in the Disks table.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Attach disk success</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Attach disk success</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The data disk that you just attached to the virtual machine is offline and not initialized after you add it.
trans-unit.target: The data disk that you just attached to the virtual machine is offline and not initialized after you add it.

trans-unit.source: You must log on to the machine and initialize the disk to use it for storing data.
trans-unit.target: You must log on to the machine and initialize the disk to use it for storing data.

trans-unit.source: Connect to the virtual machine by using the steps listed above in How to log on to the virtual machine after you create it.
trans-unit.target: Connect to the virtual machine by using the steps listed above in How to log on to the virtual machine after you create it.

trans-unit.source: In the SSH window, type the following command, and then enter the account password:
trans-unit.target: In the SSH window, type the following command, and then enter the account password:

trans-unit.source: sudo grep SCSI /var/log/messages
trans-unit.target: sudo grep SCSI /var/log/messages

trans-unit.source: You can find the identifier of the last data disk that was added in the messages that are displayed.
trans-unit.target: You can find the identifier of the last data disk that was added in the messages that are displayed.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Identify disk</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Identify disk</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the SSH window, type the following command to create a new device, and then enter the account password:
trans-unit.target: In the SSH window, type the following command to create a new device, and then enter the account password:

trans-unit.source: sudo fdisk /dev/sdc
trans-unit.target: sudo fdisk /dev/sdc

trans-unit.source: In this example you may need to use sudo -i on some distributions if /sbin or /usr/sbin are not in your $PATH.
trans-unit.target: In this example you may need to use sudo -i on some distributions if /sbin or /usr/sbin are not in your $PATH.

trans-unit.source: Type n to create a new partition.
trans-unit.target: Type n to create a new partition.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create new device</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create new device</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Type p to make the partition the primary partition, type 1 to make it the first partition, and then type enter to accept the default value for the cylinder.
trans-unit.target: Type p to make the partition the primary partition, type 1 to make it the first partition, and then type enter to accept the default value for the cylinder.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create partition</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create partition</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Type p to see the details about the disk that is being partitioned.
trans-unit.target: Type p to see the details about the disk that is being partitioned.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>List disk information</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>List disk information</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Type w to write the settings for the disk.
trans-unit.target: Type w to write the settings for the disk.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Write the disk changes</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Write the disk changes</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You must create the file system on the new partition.
trans-unit.target: You must create the file system on the new partition.

trans-unit.source: As an example, type the following command to create the file system, and then enter the account password:
trans-unit.target: As an example, type the following command to create the file system, and then enter the account password:

trans-unit.source: sudo mkfs -t ext4 /dev/sdc1
trans-unit.target: sudo mkfs -t ext4 /dev/sdc1

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create file system</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create file system</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Note that on SUSE Linux Enterprise 11 systems provide only read-only access for ext4 file systems.
trans-unit.target: Note that on SUSE Linux Enterprise 11 systems provide only read-only access for ext4 file systems.

trans-unit.source: For these systems it is recommended to format the new file system as ext3 rather than ext4.
trans-unit.target: For these systems it is recommended to format the new file system as ext3 rather than ext4.

trans-unit.source: Next you must have a directory available to mount the new file system.
trans-unit.target: Next you must have a directory available to mount the new file system.

trans-unit.source: As an example, type the following command to make a new directory for mounting the drive, and then enter the account password:
trans-unit.target: As an example, type the following command to make a new directory for mounting the drive, and then enter the account password:

trans-unit.source: sudo mkdir /datadrive
trans-unit.target: sudo mkdir /datadrive

trans-unit.source: Type the following command to mount the drive:
trans-unit.target: Type the following command to mount the drive:

trans-unit.source: sudo mount /dev/sdc1 /datadrive
trans-unit.target: sudo mount /dev/sdc1 /datadrive

trans-unit.source: The data disk is now ready to use as /datadrive.
trans-unit.target: The data disk is now ready to use as /datadrive.
